articles.title: JWST captures stunning 3D view of a planet’s scorching atmosphere
articles.summary: A team of astronomers used the James Webb Space Telescope to create the first 3D atmospheric map of an exoplanet. The fiery WASP-18b, a massive “ultra-hot Jupiter,” revealed striking temperature contrasts, including regions so hot they destroy water molecules. This pioneering eclipse mapping technique lets scientists visualize alien weather in unprecedented detail and could soon be applied to smaller, rocky planets.
articles.content:
Astronomers have produced the first three-dimensional map of a planet outside our solar system, revealing distinct temperature regions, including one so hot that water vapor breaks apart. The findings appear in Nature Astronomy, published October 28, 2025.

Led by researchers at the University of Maryland and Cornell University, the study charts temperatures across WASP-18b, a massive gas giant classified as an "ultra-hot Jupiter" located 400 light-years from Earth. The team applied a method known as 3D eclipse mapping, also called spectroscopic eclipse mapping, marking the first time this technique has been used to build a full 3D temperature map. The work expands on a 2D eclipse map the group released in 2023 using highly sensitive observations from NASA's James Webb Space Telescope (JWST).

"This technique is really the only one that can probe all three dimensions at once: latitude, longitude and altitude," said the paper's co-lead author Megan Weiner Mansfield, an assistant professor of astronomy at UMD. "This gives us a higher level of detail than we've ever had to study these celestial bodies."

With this approach, scientists can begin charting atmospheric differences across many exoplanets observable by JWST, much as ground-based telescopes once documented Jupiter's Great Red Spot and its banded clouds.

"Eclipse mapping allows us to image exoplanets that we can't see directly, because their host stars are too bright," said the paper's co-lead author Ryan Challener, a postdoctoral associate in Cornell University's Department of Astronomy. "With this telescope and this new technique, we can start to understand exoplanets along the same lines as our solar system neighbors."

Spotting exoplanets is difficult because they are typically far dimmer than their stars, often contributing less than 1% of the total light. Eclipse mapping measures tiny variations in that light as the planet moves behind its star, alternately hiding and revealing different regions. By tying these small brightness changes to specific locations on the planet and analyzing them in multiple colors, scientists can reconstruct temperatures across latitude, longitude, and altitude.

WASP-18b is well suited for this test because it has about the mass of 10 Jupiters, completes an orbit in only 23 hours, and reaches temperatures near 5,000 degrees Fahrenheit. Those properties provide a comparatively strong signal for the new mapping method.

The team's earlier 2D map used a single color of light. For the 3D version, they reanalyzed the same JWST data from the Near-Infrared Imager and Slitless Spectrograph (NIRISS) across many wavelengths. Each color probes different layers of WASP-18b's atmosphere and corresponds to a specific temperature and altitude. Combining these layers yields a detailed three-dimensional temperature structure.

"If you build a map at a wavelength that water absorbs, you'll see the water deck in the atmosphere, whereas a wavelength that water does not absorb will probe deeper," Challener explained. "If you put those together, you can get a 3D map of the temperatures in this atmosphere."

The 3D analysis identifies spectroscopically distinct zones on the planet's permanent dayside, which always faces the star because the planet is tidally locked. A circular hot spot sits where the star's light strikes most directly, and winds appear too weak to spread that heat efficiently. A cooler ring encircles the hot center near the limb of the planet. Measurements also show reduced water vapor within the hot spot compared with the planet's average.

"We've seen this happen on a population level, where you can see a cooler planet that has water and then a hotter planet that doesn't have water," Weiner Mansfield explained. "But this is the first time we've seen this be broken across one planet instead. It's one atmosphere, but we see cooler regions that have water and hotter regions where the water's being broken apart. That had been predicted by theory, but it's really exciting to actually see this with real observations."

Additional JWST observations could sharpen the spatial detail in future 3D eclipse maps. Weiner Mansfield noted that the method opens new opportunities to study many "hot Jupiters," which number in the hundreds among the more than 6,000 confirmed exoplanets. She also aims to apply 3D eclipse mapping to smaller, rocky worlds beyond gas giants like WASP-18b.

"It's very exciting to finally have the tools to see and map out the temperatures of a different planet in this much detail. It's set us up to possibly use the technique on other types of exoplanets. For example, if a planet doesn't have an atmosphere, we can still use the technique to map the temperature of the surface itself to possibly understand its composition," Mansfield said. "Although WASP-18b was more predictable, I believe we will have the chance to see things that we could never have expected before."

This research was supported by the James Webb Space Telescope's Transiting Exoplanet Community Early Release Science Program.

articles.personality_title: James Webb creates first 3D map of a distant planet’s fiery atmosphere
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists want to understand the weather and temperatures on planets outside our solar system, called exoplanets. These planets are very far away and usually hidden by the bright light of their stars, making them hard to study.

**What happened** – Using NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope (JWST), astronomers made the first-ever three-dimensional map of an exoplanet’s atmosphere. They focused on WASP-18b, a huge planet about 400 light-years from Earth. This planet is extremely hot, with temperatures reaching nearly 5,000 degrees Fahrenheit. The researchers used a special method called 3D eclipse mapping, which looks at changes in light as the planet moves behind its star to measure temperatures at different heights and places on the planet.

**Impact** – This new 3D map shows regions on WASP-18b where it is so hot that water molecules break apart, and cooler areas where water still exists. Scientists can now see detailed weather patterns on distant worlds, not just flat images. This is the first time such detailed temperature differences have been seen on a single exoplanet. It helps us understand how planets outside our solar system behave and how their atmospheres work.

**What's next step** – Researchers plan to use this 3D mapping technique on many other exoplanets, including smaller, rocky ones that might be more like Earth. They hope to learn about different types of atmospheres and even map the surface temperatures of planets without atmospheres. This method could reveal surprising new details about distant worlds.

**One-sentence takeaway** – For the first time, scientists have used the James Webb Space Telescope to create a detailed 3D temperature map of a distant planet’s atmosphere, revealing how heat and water vapor change across its surface and height.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le James Webb crée la première carte 3D de l’atmosphère brûlante d’une planète lointaine
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques veulent comprendre le climat et les températures des planètes situées en dehors de notre système solaire, appelées exoplanètes. Ces planètes sont très éloignées et souvent cachées par la lumière brillante de leurs étoiles, ce qui rend leur étude difficile.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Grâce au télescope spatial James Webb (JWST) de la NASA, des astronomes ont réalisé la toute première carte tridimensionnelle de l’atmosphère d’une exoplanète. Ils ont étudié WASP-18b, une énorme planète située à environ 400 années-lumière de la Terre. Cette planète est extrêmement chaude, avec des températures proches de 2 760 degrés Celsius. Les chercheurs ont utilisé une méthode spéciale appelée cartographie d’éclipse 3D, qui mesure les variations de lumière lorsque la planète passe derrière son étoile pour déterminer les températures à différentes altitudes et endroits sur la planète.

**Impact** – Cette nouvelle carte 3D montre des zones sur WASP-18b où il fait tellement chaud que les molécules d’eau se décomposent, et des zones plus fraîches où l’eau est encore présente. Les scientifiques peuvent désormais observer les phénomènes météorologiques détaillés de mondes lointains, et pas seulement des images plates. C’est la première fois que des différences de température aussi précises sont vues sur une seule exoplanète. Cela aide à mieux comprendre le fonctionnement des planètes en dehors de notre système solaire.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs prévoient d’utiliser cette technique de cartographie 3D sur de nombreuses autres exoplanètes, y compris des planètes plus petites et rocheuses, plus proches de la Terre. Ils espèrent découvrir différents types d’atmosphères et même cartographier les températures de surface des planètes sans atmosphère. Cette méthode pourrait révéler des détails surprenants sur ces mondes lointains.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – Pour la première fois, les scientifiques ont utilisé le télescope James Webb pour créer une carte 3D détaillée des températures dans l’atmosphère d’une planète lointaine, révélant comment la chaleur et la vapeur d’eau varient à travers sa surface et en hauteur.
articles.personality_title_es: El James Webb crea el primer mapa 3D de la atmósfera ardiente de un planeta distante
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos quieren entender el clima y las temperaturas de planetas fuera de nuestro sistema solar, llamados exoplanetas. Estos planetas están muy lejos y suelen estar ocultos por la luz brillante de sus estrellas, lo que dificulta estudiarlos.

**Qué pasó** – Usando el telescopio espacial James Webb (JWST) de la NASA, los astrónomos crearon el primer mapa tridimensional del clima de un exoplaneta. Se enfocaron en WASP-18b, un planeta enorme a unos 400 años luz de la Tierra. Este planeta es extremadamente caliente, con temperaturas cercanas a los 2,760 grados Celsius. Los investigadores usaron un método especial llamado mapeo de eclipse 3D, que mide los cambios en la luz cuando el planeta pasa detrás de su estrella para detectar temperaturas en diferentes alturas y lugares del planeta.

**Impacto** – Este nuevo mapa 3D muestra áreas en WASP-18b donde hace tanto calor que las moléculas de agua se descomponen, y zonas más frías donde el agua todavía existe. Ahora los científicos pueden ver patrones detallados del clima en mundos lejanos, no solo imágenes planas. Es la primera vez que se observan diferencias de temperatura tan precisas en un solo exoplaneta. Esto ayuda a entender cómo funcionan las atmósferas de planetas fuera de nuestro sistema solar.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores planean usar esta técnica de mapeo 3D en muchos otros exoplanetas, incluyendo algunos más pequeños y rocosos que podrían ser más parecidos a la Tierra. Esperan aprender sobre diferentes tipos de atmósferas e incluso mapear las temperaturas de la superficie de planetas sin atmósfera. Este método podría revelar detalles sorprendentes sobre mundos distantes.

**Una frase clave** – Por primera vez, los científicos usaron el telescopio James Webb para crear un mapa 3D detallado de la temperatura en la atmósfera de un planeta distante, mostrando cómo cambian el calor y el vapor de agua en su superficie y altura.
